nmr-principle.name: NMR Principle
nmr-principle.correct: NMR detects nuclei with spin placed in a magnetic field that absorb radio waves

detects electrons in orbitals.error: Confusing NMR with UV-visible - NMR detects nuclei, not electrons
detects electrons in orbitals.fix: NMR detects nuclear spin transitions, not electronic transitions
detects electrons in orbitals.action: Remember: NMR = Nuclear Magnetic Resonance = nuclei, not electrons

uses infrared radiation.error: Confusing NMR with IR - NMR uses radio waves, IR uses infrared
uses infrared radiation.fix: NMR uses low-energy radio waves; IR uses higher-energy infrared radiation
uses infrared radiation.action: Match: NMR = radio waves, IR = infrared, UV-vis = ultraviolet/visible

breaks chemical bonds.error: NMR is non-destructive and doesn't break bonds
breaks chemical bonds.fix: Radio waves in NMR are low energy and only flip nuclear spins
breaks chemical bonds.action: NMR is a non-destructive technique - sample remains unchanged

persistent.gap: Not understanding NMR uses radio waves to detect nuclear spin
persistent.action: Focus on nuclei absorbing radio waves when placed in a magnetic field

c13-isotope.name: Carbon-13 Isotope
c13-isotope.correct: ¹³C makes up about 1% of natural carbon and has nuclear spin

100% abundant.error: Confusing ¹³C with ¹²C abundance - ¹³C is rare
100% abundant.fix: ¹³C is only ~1% abundant; ¹²C (98.9%) has no nuclear spin and is NMR-silent
100% abundant.action: Low abundance of ¹³C means longer acquisition times needed for good spectra

has no nuclear spin.error: Confusing ¹³C with ¹²C - only ¹³C has spin and is NMR-active
has no nuclear spin.fix: ¹³C has spin of ½ and is NMR-active; ¹²C has spin of 0 and is NMR-silent
has no nuclear spin.action: Even number of protons AND neutrons = no spin (¹²C); odd total = spin (¹³C)

is radioactive.error: Confusing ¹³C with ¹⁴C - ¹³C is stable
is radioactive.fix: ¹³C is a stable isotope; ¹⁴C is the radioactive isotope used in carbon dating
is radioactive.action: ¹³C-NMR uses stable ¹³C, not radioactive ¹⁴C

persistent.gap: Not recognising ¹³C as the NMR-active carbon isotope at 1% abundance
persistent.action: Remember: ¹³C is rare (1%) but has spin; ¹²C is common (99%) but has no spin

chemical-shift.name: Chemical Shift
chemical-shift.correct: Chemical shift in ppm measures how shielded a nucleus is relative to TMS

measured in cm⁻¹.error: Confusing NMR with IR - NMR uses ppm, IR uses cm⁻¹
measured in cm⁻¹.fix: Chemical shift is measured in parts per million (ppm), not wavenumber
measured in cm⁻¹.action: NMR x-axis = ppm (δ); IR x-axis = cm⁻¹

increases for more shielded carbons.error: Reversing the relationship - more shielded = lower chemical shift
increases for more shielded carbons.fix: More shielded carbons appear at lower chemical shift (closer to TMS at 0 ppm)
increases for more shielded carbons.action: Shielded = upfield = lower δ; Deshielded = downfield = higher δ

measured in Hz.error: Using frequency instead of normalised units
measured in Hz.fix: Chemical shift in ppm is independent of spectrometer frequency, making comparison easier
measured in Hz.action: ppm is used so spectra from different instruments can be compared

persistent.gap: Not understanding chemical shift as a measure of nuclear shielding in ppm
persistent.action: Higher δ = more deshielded = electron-withdrawing groups nearby

tms-reference.name: TMS Reference
tms-reference.correct: TMS (tetramethylsilane) is the reference at 0 ppm because its carbons are highly shielded

appears at 200 ppm.error: Wrong position - TMS defines 0 ppm by convention
appears at 200 ppm.fix: TMS is the reference standard and is defined as 0 ppm
appears at 200 ppm.action: TMS = 0 ppm (all other signals measured relative to this)

contains oxygen atoms.error: Wrong structure - TMS is Si(CH₃)₄ with no oxygen
contains oxygen atoms.fix: TMS is tetramethylsilane Si(CH₃)₄, containing Si, C, and H only
contains oxygen atoms.action: TMS structure: Si with four CH₃ groups attached

its carbons are deshielded.error: Opposite is true - TMS carbons are highly shielded
its carbons are deshielded.fix: TMS carbons are highly shielded because Si is less electronegative than C
its carbons are deshielded.action: Si is electropositive, pushing electron density onto C, shielding them

persistent.gap: Not understanding TMS as the 0 ppm reference due to shielded carbons
persistent.action: TMS at 0 ppm; all other carbons are more deshielded (positive δ values)

carbon-environments.name: Carbon Environments
carbon-environments.correct: Equivalent carbons in the same chemical environment produce one peak

each carbon atom gives a separate peak.error: Not recognising equivalence - equivalent carbons give one peak
each carbon atom gives a separate peak.fix: Carbons in identical chemical environments are equivalent and give a single peak
each carbon atom gives a separate peak.action: Count unique environments, not total carbons (e.g., ethane has 2 C but 1 peak)

symmetry doesn't affect the spectrum.error: Missing the role of molecular symmetry
symmetry doesn't affect the spectrum.fix: Molecular symmetry creates equivalent carbons that appear as one peak
symmetry doesn't affect the spectrum.action: Look for symmetry planes or rotation axes to identify equivalent carbons

number of peaks equals molecular formula.error: Confusing total carbons with unique environments
number of peaks equals molecular formula.fix: Number of peaks = number of unique carbon environments, which may be less than total carbons
number of peaks equals molecular formula.action: Propan-2-ol (C₃H₈O) shows 2 peaks: 2 equivalent CH₃ + 1 CH

persistent.gap: Not using symmetry to identify equivalent carbon environments
persistent.action: Identify symmetry first, then count non-equivalent carbon positions

chemical-shift-ranges.name: Chemical Shift Ranges
chemical-shift-ranges.correct: Different carbon types appear in characteristic chemical shift ranges

all carbons appear at the same shift.fix: Carbon chemical shift depends on attached atoms and nearby groups
all carbons appear at the same shift.action: Carbons near electronegative atoms are deshielded (higher δ)

carbonyl carbon appears at 0-50 ppm.error: Wrong range - carbonyl is at high chemical shift
carbonyl carbon appears at 0-50 ppm.fix: C=O appears 160-220 ppm; alkyl carbons at 0-50 ppm
carbonyl carbon appears at 0-50 ppm.action: Carbonyl carbons are highly deshielded (high δ) due to C=O polarity

aromatic carbons appear below 100 ppm.error: Wrong range - aromatic carbons are more deshielded
aromatic carbons appear below 100 ppm.action: Aromatic carbons are deshielded by ring current effects

persistent.gap: Not knowing typical chemical shift ranges for different carbon types
persistent.action: Learn key ranges: alkyl 0-50, aromatic 110-160, carbonyl 160-220 ppm

electronegativity-effect.name: Electronegativity Effect
electronegativity-effect.correct: Electronegative atoms withdraw electrons, deshielding nearby carbons and increasing chemical shift

electronegative atoms shield carbons.fix: Electronegative atoms withdraw electron density, deshielding carbons (higher δ)
electronegative atoms shield carbons.action: Higher electronegativity = less electron density = less shielding = higher δ

electronegativity has no effect on chemi.error: Missing the major factor affecting chemical shift
electronegativity has no effect on chemi.fix: Electronegativity is the main factor determining ¹³C chemical shift
electronegativity has no effect on chemi.action: Compare: C-I < C-Br < C-Cl < C-F in chemical shift (increasing EN)

only directly attached atoms affect shif.fix: Electronegativity effects extend through several bonds, though decreasing
only directly attached atoms affect shif.action: C-C-Cl shows effect on both carbons, strongest on carbon attached to Cl

persistent.gap: Not connecting electronegativity to deshielding and chemical shift
persistent.action: More electronegative neighbours = more deshielded = higher chemical shift

spectrum-counting.name: Peak Counting
spectrum-counting.correct: The number of peaks indicates the number of unique carbon environments

peak height indicates number of carbons.error: Unlike ¹H-NMR, ¹³C peak heights are not quantitative
peak height indicates number of carbons.fix: ¹³C-NMR peak heights are unreliable for counting carbons due to varying relaxation times
peak height indicates number of carbons.action: Count peaks for environments, but don't use heights for carbon ratios

more peaks means larger molecule.error: Confusing peak number with molecular size
more peaks means larger molecule.fix: Highly symmetric large molecules may show fewer peaks than small asymmetric ones
more peaks means larger molecule.action: Benzene (C₆H₆) shows 1 peak; propan-1-ol (C₃H₈O) shows 3 peaks

equivalent carbons give multiple peaks.fix: Equivalent carbons give exactly one peak regardless of how many
equivalent carbons give multiple peaks.action: Look for molecular symmetry to identify equivalent carbons

persistent.gap: Not correctly using peak count to determine carbon environments
persistent.action: Number of peaks = number of unique carbon environments (use symmetry)

explanations.nmr-principle: NMR spectroscopy detects nuclei with spin that absorb radio waves when placed in a magnetic field.

explanations.chemical-shift: Chemical shift (δ) in ppm measures nuclear shielding relative to TMS; higher values indicate deshielding.
